steps.explanation: Keeping up to date with vaccinations is crucial, especially for older adults and individuals with underlying health conditions, as it significantly reduces the risk of severe illness, hospitalization, and death from COVID-19.

Following standard preventive actions, such as mask-wearing, social distancing, and hand hygiene, is important, particularly if you are older or have pre-existing health issues. These measures help minimize the risk of contracting and spreading the virus.

citations.excerpt:
People with Certain Medical Conditions and COVID-19 Risk Factors
For Everyone
June 11, 2025
Español
What to know
• If you have any medical conditions listed below, you are more likely to get very sick
with COVID-19.
• This list does not include all conditions.
• If you have symptoms consistent with ...

steps.text: Seek treatment within 5-7 days of symptom onset
steps.explanation: Initiate treatment as soon as possible, ideally within 5 to 7 days from when symptoms first appear. Early treatment is crucial for reducing the risk of hospitalization and potential mortality associated with COVID-19.

steps.text: Consider visiting a Test to Treat location
steps.explanation: Explore the option of visiting a designated 'Test to Treat' location. These sites offer immediate testing and, if positive, provide on-the-spot treatment based on your condition and risk factors.

steps.text: Consult healthcare provider about vaccination for children
steps.explanation: Parents of children aged 6 months to 17 years should consult with their healthcare provider to discuss the benefits and recommendations for COVID-19 vaccination. Vaccination is an important preventive measure.

Specific information on children and teens
People of all ages, including children and teens, can get very sick from COVID-19,
especially those with underlying medical conditions. This includes children and teens with:
• Medical complexity
• Genetic, neurologic, or metabolic cond...

steps.text: Vaccinate children and teens against COVID-19.
steps.explanation: Parents of children aged 6 months to 17 years should consult with a healthcare provider to discuss the advantages of COVID-19 vaccination. Vaccination is especially important for those with underlying medical conditions.

steps.text: Consult a healthcare provider for specific medical condition advice.
steps.explanation: If you have questions about managing a condition or protecting yourself from COVID-19, especially if the condition is not explicitly listed, consult with your healthcare provider for tailored guidance.

steps.text: Consider Pemivibart (Pemgarda™) for immunocompromised patients (12+ years, >=88 pounds).
steps.explanation: For moderately to severely immunocompromised individuals aged 12 years and older, weighing at least 88 pounds, Pemivibart (Pemgarda™) can provide an additional layer of protection against COVID-19, even after vaccination. It should be administered at least 2 weeks post-vaccination.

steps.text: Consult healthcare provider about additional precautions for immunocompromised patients.
steps.explanation: Immunocompromised individuals, including those with cancer on chemotherapy, organ transplant recipients, or those on long-term corticosteroids, may require extra precautions. Discuss specific needs with their healthcare provider.

steps.text: Consider additional COVID-19 vaccine doses for moderately or severely immunocompromised.
steps.explanation: Due to potentially differing immune responses post-vaccination, moderately or severely immunocompromised individuals might benefit from additional doses of the updated COVID-19 vaccine. Refer to specific guidance for dosage.

include:

steps.text: Consult healthcare provider on additional precautions.
steps.explanation: Immunocompromised individuals, even when vaccinated, might require extra preventive measures. Discuss specific risks and necessary precautions with a healthcare provider to ensure adequate protection.

Moderately to severely immunocompromised individuals might benefit from extra doses of the updated COVID-19 vaccine. This is due to potentially differing immune responses following vaccination in this population.

Moderately or severely immunocompromised individuals aged 12 and older, weighing at least 88 pounds, might be eligible for Pemivibart, a monoclonal antibody, to help protect against COVID-19. It can be given at least 2 weeks after a COVID-19 vaccine.
